bibl.title: Letter from Joseph B. Brown to the Surgeon General, March 23, 1882

div1.p: Brown reports to the Surgeon General that the Board has examined Reed and considers him qualified for a promotion, with the proviso that he continues his studies in Physics. A second letter written on March 24, 1882 by C. H. Crane informs Reed of the outcome of the examination. The letters are accompanied by an endorsement.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph B. Brown to the Surgeon General, March 23, 1882
div1.p:
Sec. Hinne, Charlie K.
Asst. Surg. U.S.A.

Army Medical Ex. Board,
New York City, Mar. 23d 1882.

Brown Joseph B
Surgeon U. S. Army
President Board.

Reports that Asst. Surgeon
Walter Reed U. S. Army, was
carefully examined to day and
found, physically and profession-
ally, qualified for promotion,
but it is recommended that
in future he be directed to pay
more attention to Physics, one of
the branches he was deficient in
at his first examination.

Dr Reed informed
March 24/82_ Extract
furnished.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph B. Brown to the Surgeon General, March 23, 1882
div1.opener:
Army Medical Examining Board,
New York City, March 23d 1882.
Surgeon General U. S. Army,
Washington, D. C.
Sir
div1.p:
I have the honor to report that Assis-
tant Surgeon Walter Reed, U. S. Army, having
reported to the Board, in compliance with Special
Orders No. 58, Headquarters of the Army, Washington,
March 13th 1882, has this day been carefully examined.

He is considered to be qualified for
permotion, both physically and professionally,
but it is recommended that he be directed to
continue his studies in Physics, one of the subjects
in which he was deficient at his first examination.
The papers relating to his case, are herewith returned.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
Your obedient Servant, Joseph B Brown Surgeon U. S. Army,
President Board.

div1.head: Letter from C. H. Crane to Walter Reed, March 24, 1882
div1.opener:
[unclear]/1882.
S.G.O. March 24/82
Captain Walter Reed,
Assistant Surgeon U. S. Army,
Washington Barracks,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I am instructed by the Surgeon Gene-
-ral to inform you that upon examination
by the Army Medical Board, in New York City, New
York, on the 23rd instant, you were found
physically and professionally qualified for
promotion.

The following extract from the
report of the President of the Board is
furnished for your information and guidance.
"“He is considered to be qualified for promotion
" both physically and professionally, but it is
" recommended that he be directed to continue
" his studies in Physics, one of the subjects
" in which he was dificient at his first
" examination.”
